title: Does the Descartes ontological argument reversing God’s status from nominative to accusative simplify to mean I am because of God to God is because I am? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes because it places the thinking self as the basis and foundation for all knowledge, which includes the knowledge of God. God is an object of knowledge.  That is the  standard view of Descartes as the hinge of modernity - which also has the kernel of later atheistic thinking.  The earlier scholastic  view was something like knowledge is all  divine revelation and human intelligence is more or less in tune with that. This book goes over it pretty well:A Short History of Atheism

Not only does it reverse God's status, but it reverses the world's status. Previously, in scholastic, Aristotelian realism, one could say that I am because the world is, but with Descartes it became the world is because I am.  The world became an idea in my mind which I projected outward. Descartes was the beginning of Idealism.

No.   It's not necessary to reference grammatical cases or the origin of oneself to understand Descartes' argument.    Descartes simply maintains that any clear and distinct conception of God would entail knowledge that God actually exists.
If not for us God would not exist. If not for God we would not exist. Quoting another reasoning, a mountain can only be if there is a valley. Then we must conclude that we are one.
